title: As a parent, are you comfortable with teachers instilling their own political beliefs in your children? - Quora

response.answer_text: Yes — up to a point. One of the answers here notes: I think it is the purpose for education to supply information, and prepare a student for the next level. While that might be superficially true for the youngest students, education should be so much ore than that. Students should learn how to think, how to digest what they are taught, how to read and analyze critically, and how to form their own views, outlooks, and opinions. In other words, if teachers are “instilling their own political beliefs in their children,” those students should learn how to receive those beliefs, how to analyze them, and how to counter them, if need be. If students are simply being supplied with information, their teachers are only doing a small part of their jobs. And, in general, the students will be bored. My sophomore year in college I took a course called “Medieval and Early Renaissance European History.” On the first day of the first class, the professor announced that he was a Marxist and an atheist, and that he despised organized religion. While I appreciated his being up front about his beliefs, my immediate thought that I should drop this class, since Medieval and Early Renaissance European History is completely dominated, in one way or another, by the Catholic Church. So, not only was I going to be taught a subject from a biassed point of view, as a Catholic, I would have to sit through an entire semester of Catholic bashing. But I decided not to drop the class and to stick with it. And I’m very glad I did. Not only was he a fascinating lecturer, but he helped me achieve exactly what I was in college to achieve: A critical mind, a true sense of inquisitiveness, and a ability to thing and analyze in the bigger picture. I disagreed with his views on many topics, and he did engage in a lot of needless (and sometimes irrelevant) Catholic bashing. But he taught me to form my own views and, perhaps best of all, to challenge my preconceived notions and opinions. He didn’t really change my mind about anything, but he certainly helped me form my mind. And that’s pretty much the whole point.

I think it is the purpose for education to supply information, and prepare a student for the next level, encouraging along the way. A person, young or old, should learn how to process information according to their age and development. It is very reasonable to ask for an appointment with this teacher to discuss this. If you both are capable of agreeing to educate and not force views on your child then your child is on the road to being a well rounded adult. I am hopeful that neither you or the teacher (both positions of authority who your child likely wants to please) is stating a preference that is believed to be 100% right. You can explain why you believe what you do. The educator can do the same. Your child will work it out according to age and development. Most importantly your child will not be afraid of the risk that you or his/her teacher is angry.

As a parent, are you comfortable with teachers instilling their own political beliefs in your children? Sure. My beliefs are passed on to my kids and are strong enough to withstand other ideas. Further, if my ideas are incorrect, it would be good for the teachers to expose them to new ideas.

I’m a teacher and the answer is no. Teachers should NOT install their political beliefs in a student. I teach government and election in social studies but I never interject my political beliefs. My students never know my party affiliation.nor do they know who I voted for in an election. I also do NOT allow them to speak badly about any President. Ever.
I’m fine with them sharing their political beliefs if they respect the kids’ ability to think for themselves.

As a good parent before you children get to school how and what you believe and if it's an opposing point of view it is the perfect time to talk about it probably one of the best ways to learn is honest debate
